page.title: 02The Roe Deer of Kielder
page.content: Roe deer are now plentiful in the Kielder Forests, with their numbers having increased dramatically since planting first started in 1926. Up to 5000 now roam the forest. The deer prefer the younger parts of the forest, which provide them with shelter as well as food and cover, but they are found in older sections too. It is possible to observe roe deer early in the morning, as they move back into cover, and in quiet areas they may also be seen during the day. The best time of year for such observations is May and June, when kids are born and adults shed their winter coat and replace it with brighter red summer colours. Culling is carried out by forest rangers, to prevent over-population and possible starvation.
